debate_summary: The study investigates the preference for AI regulation in Europe, examining the influence of cultural dimensions, particularly uncertainty avoidance, on people's perceived risks associated with AI. The findings suggest that individuals in cultures with higher uncertainty avoidance are more likely to perceive risks such as a lack of accountability and responsibility in AI systems. This perception drives their preference for government regulation over self-regulation. While the study acknowledges the role of government regulation in addressing accountability, it also highlights that industry self-regulation can be effective in managing responsibility-related concerns, indicating a nuanced view that supports a balance between self-regulation and government oversight in the AI sector.
key_points: Higher levels of uncertainty avoidance correlate with increased perceptions of AI risks, particularly regarding accountability (B = 0.015**) and responsibility (B = 0.010*).
58.41% of respondents prefer government regulation to ensure ethical AI applications, influenced by perceived risks of accountability and responsibility.
Only 17.71% of respondents prefer industry self-regulation, indicating skepticism about the industry's ability to govern itself effectively.
The study finds that perceived AI risks significantly drive preferences for government regulation (lack of accountability: B = 0.319***, lack of responsibility: B = 0.326***).

Uncertainty avoidance is significantly related to preferences for industry self-regulation when controlling for perceived AI risks (B = 0.016**), suggesting a context where self-regulation can be acceptable if responsibility-related concerns are mitigated.
author: Bartosz Wilczek, Sina Thäsler-Kordonouri, Maximilian Eder
title: Government regulation or industry self-regulation of AI? Investigating the relationships between uncertainty avoidance, people’s AI risk perceptions, and their regulatory preferences in Europe
